context: Apparently these brilliant folks have no clue as to how the British monarchy actually works. The queen, now king, is the head of state, but all laws and policies are made by Parliament. The monarch does not make law or policy, and has no actual power to influence law or policy.

replies.context: But I bet you aren't aware of a clause in Britain that states at any time, The King or Queen can dissolve Parliament and take absolute power.

That‚Äôs negative speed racer. When King George VI was very active with the selection of Prime Minister during WWII. He gave the nod to Churchill. Since, most of the male monarchy has military backgrounds king George VI was no different. However, the monarchy, even during WWII had primarily honorary functions.
Did anyone of those kings or queens do that?
Parliament is supreme and can alter any aspect of the British Constitution. Any monarch who did what you suggest would create a constitutional crisis, likely ending the monarchy.
Google is your friend, so is Wiki - "Royal prerogative" << Google that.

Are you really going argue the royal  prerogative would last past the first time a modern British monarch tried to use it? Seriously? Do you understand that under the British Constitution, Parliament is supreme, even over the monarch and
can abolish the royal prerogative at anytime?

At what point did I say there that THEY WOULD USE IT? 
"But I bet you aren't aware of a clause in Britain that states at any time, The King or Queen can dissolve Parliament and take absolute power."
Did I say what would happen, or suggest they'd use it? "Can" does not equate to "WILL."

Your point is pretty useless. One, the issue is whether the queen should be expected to speak on political issues. The answer is no. Secondly, whether the monarch can unilaterally dissolve Parliament is moot since no monarch would do so, as the Parliament would either abolish the prerogative or perhaps abolish the monarchy. An no the king could not take absolute power as the monarch has no authority to enact laws. Under the British constitution the parliament is supreme. Only the Parliament can enact law. No monarch would be foolish enough to to challenge that. So your point is meaningless and has nothing to do with the issue raised in the article. By the way, Britain has no written constitution, so there is no ‚Äúclause.‚Äù I also suggest you reread the Wikipedia article about the royal prerogative. It is far less certain than you think that the monarch may unilaterally dissolve Parliament.
